subsection_content:
The doctor will examine the nasopharynx and larynx to see if there is any damage in this area causing hoarseness. In addition, if abnormalities are detected, the doctor may order tests.
Some tests to diagnose hoarseness often include routine laryngoscopy and stroboscopic laryngoscopy.(2)
Stroboscopic laryngoscopy: is an examination of the larynx using a flashing light from a fiber optic light source to record slow-moving video images of vocal cord activity, combined with a rigid or flexible laryngoscope. . This method allows checking the vibration of the vocal cords and the opening and closing activity of the vocal cords, clearly showing vocal cord lesions suspected of tumors or benign vocal cord lesions.
Photo: Patients should see a doctor if hoarseness lasts for more than 2 weeks without improvement.
